summary: A clash between good and evil awaits as young Harry (Daniel Radcliffe), Ron (Rupert Grint) and Hermione (Emma Watson) prepare for a final battle against Lord Voldemort (Ralph Fiennes). Harry has grown into a steely lad on a mission to rid the world of evil. The friends must search for the Horcruxes that keep the dastardly wizard immortal. Harry and Voldemort meet at Hogwarts Castle for an epic showdown where the forces of darkness may finally meet their match.

An excellent end to this franchise. From the moment the opening music starts, you know that this is going to be very different from how the franchise started. Not the best movie in the series in my opinion, but nonetheless extremely enjoyable. There are a few parts that still raise more questions than answers, but these do not spoil the overall storyline, and the sequence of events around the Elder wand is not particularly convincing - more a Scooby Doo explanation than Hercule Poirot. The final ending is quite funny as the actors have not been made to look old enough for the roles in the very final scenes.  Unlike many multi part stories that have an unsatisfactory ending, this is a must watch once you have seen the rest.

The Harry Potter saga tells us about the adventures of the young magic and sorcery apprentice Harry Potter and his friends Hermione Granger and Ron Weasley, during the years they spend at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, who spends his life training to defeat the enemy voldemort, in my opinion, the story is very good, the special effects are great and the characters are really good since they interpret it in the best way. In my personal impression, the saga is very good, since I really like magic, and the characters that come out are played by actors and actresses that I really like. A recommendation that I would give him would be that they had not made so many films, since some are filler.

Wow, this is all I can really say after viewing this climatic and powerfully acted finale to the decade long Harry Potter franchise!  Truly epic in every sense of the word, "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows- Part 2" is a stunning and powerful achievement!  I don't think a better conclusion to such a beloved and magical series could have been obtained by changing anything in this film!  From start to finish the film is relentless, much like Lord Voldemort and the film's 2+ running time flies by in the blink of an eye.  We finally learn and accept the fates of all our characters and what their legacy is.  My favorite character throughout (Alan Rickman as Professor Snape) is finally justified and his childhood examined, giving tremendous insight and emotional pull to his actions.  During his final moments I was literally in tears knowing how hard his life was and the darkness he had to endure and yet in the end he was always a wonderful person at his core!  Not only was I emotionally devastated throughout the film but I was so thoroughly engaged that I could not take my eyes away for even the slightest moment.  The film brings together everything that made this wonderful franchise such a huge hit and brings it to the ultimate climax, deciding the fate of everyone good and bad in the process.  The impeccable special effects, wonderfully developed characters, stunning sets of the various settings, and all around general epic feel that I desired was given to me.  I could not be more happy with how it all turned out, however I shed many tears along the way especially when it came to Professor Snape and his sacrifices.  I cannot recommend this enough, although most have already seen most if not all the films, if you haven't you owe it to yourself.  You will not be disappointed!

Here it is, a cinematic event to rival them all, the epic conclusion to one of the greatest franchises of the cinema. And what a grand finale it is. The end of Harry Potter's adventure is not just one of the very best entries in the saga, it's also one of the very best films of the summer. Thrilling, tragic, funny, touching, and--most importantly--magical, it's a film that ties up loose ends, reveals some surprises, and delivers a ride that takes you across the emotional spectrum. Director David Yates and screenwriter Steve Kloves by now have a firm hand on the material and deftly move us from the solemn opening to a teary-eyed finale. The pace here is unlike most any Potter film, probably since this is the most action-packed one yet. Spirited chases, an episode with a dragon, and rousing one-on-one battles are enough to get your blood pumping, and the dazzling visuals (often brought to life by the 3D) put you in the middle of the action. But what has given this series its juice is the cast of actors, young and old, who have brought these beloved characters to vivid life. Almost all get their moment to shine, although that crammed roster (dead characters also make appearances) can trip up the momentum the film has going for itself. But sensing the end, everyone commits to their parts with a heartfelt flourish. Daniel Radcliffe, Rupert Grint, and Emma Watson are the heart and soul of the series, and have grown up with it. Seeing them wholly inhabit Harry, Ron, and Hermione's last stage in their emotional journey is one of the great movie going pleasures of recent memory. The other young men and women deliver the goods as well. Not to mention the elder thespians, who are superb, one and all. Michael Gambon, Ralph Fiennes, Alan Rickman (especially terrific), Robbie Coltrane, John Hurt, Gary Oldman, Jason Issacs, David Thewlis, Julie Walters, Mark Williams, Jim Broadbent, Emma Thompson, Imelda Staunton, Warwick Davis, and best of all, my personal favorite, the regal Maggie Smith. The two new additions to cast are Ciaran Hinds and the great Kelly McDonald, and they leave sharp impressions. Everything comes together in such a satisfying way it's really hard to see where the story could go from here, despite what potential the "next generation" epilogue offers. Over the course of seven books, eight films, and ten years, we've gone on a magical adventure with a great hero to a world both wonderfully enchanting and humanly recognizable, and we've been happy to go along and lose ourselves to the magic of it all

Magical, wonderful, beautiful, magical, action packed, mysterious, magical again!! I am just absolutely beyond words. This incredible journey has taken me to places that nobody has ever been to, and even though these seven incredible adventures have scared me to death, it has been a blast getting to know the characters, the story, the magical creatures that make you feel more alive,……….darn! I can't think of anything else to say. But still, in spite of all the dangers that came throughout the adventure, I still had an absolute blast. This experience is something that I will never forget, especially when it comes to flying a broomstick every single day, or creating random potions at Professor Snape's classroom. I'm sorry. I keep getting ahead of myself. What I'm trying to say is that this is a story that every single person out there should get their hands on. Yet, even though its hard to say goodbye to these incredible characters until next time, HARRY POTTER AND THE DEATHLY HALLOWS: PART 2 brings in multiple opportunities for those that want to be witches, wizards, and incredible adventurers in the years to come. I am forever grateful to be a part of this incredible journey in the one place that everybody wants to go to: The Wizarding World of Harry Potter. J.K. Rowling, thank you.

As the finale of the entire Harry Potter series, what 10 years of joy and heartbreak has been building up to, it's hard to imagine a much more satisfying conclusion than what is shown in Deathly Hallows Part 2.
I will admit, it does have its flaws here and there. There are a couple plot holes, lines of dialogue that reference book related material that was never placed in the movies, and an ending twist that kind of soured some of this movie's good will towards the end. But, still, those mean next to nothing to just how fantastic this movie is!
The characters are great, the music is a surprising high point of the film, the pacing quick while never feeling rushed, the action is awesome, the stakes are high, and the emotional moments hit hard.  
It's a flawed but marvelous finale to one of the best and most famous franchises in history, and (arguably) pulls off the biggest accomplishment of any ending: it tops everything that came before it.

Warning: Spoilers
I have enjoyed all the films and love the books, and after how much I loved Deathly Hallows Part 1 this entry, continuing from exactly where the previous film left off, had a lot to live up to. It is less faithful to the mammoth but very interesting and wonderful book than its predecessor. However I found this, apart from one or two disjointed parts where you could tell that details had been left out and the arrival in Hogsmede and the duel between Mrs Weasley and Bellatrix seemed a little rushed, had more flow, was better paced and had more coherent storytelling and less of admiring the scenery than the previous entries.

What stood out for me was not only the darkness of it, particularly the last thirty minutes or so which was a tad anti-climatic but very intense too and also Snape's death, but also the emotional impact. Gringotts(especially for the effects, the dragon being the standout), the moving Ressurrection stone sequence and Harry's final scene with Dumbedore were very well done, but my favourite was the Snape's memory sequence, which was beautifully done and quite poignant. Not only that, it's my favourite Harry Potter scene alongside the Three Brothers animated sequence and the Cave Scene. The 19 Years Later scene was quite affectionate as well, with the use of the original music and all.

Once again, the production values are impeccable. The effects, apart from the odd ropey one in the Room of Requirement scene and Bellatrix's death, are excellent particularly at Gringotts, while the scenery and cinematography are magical with a touch of austerity too, and David Yates delivers his best directing job. There's also my favourite of Alexandre Desplat's scores, I loved his ones for Girl with a Pearl Earring and The King's Speech, the score was also one of the few good points about Twilight:New Moon and I found his score for the previous part very effective. What I loved though about this score was not just how beautiful, haunting and how incredibly melancholic it was, but also how much it enhanced the drama.

The script is very good a vast majority of the time, doing a noble attempt to stick to the spirit of the book. The humour is less stilted and corny than I can find it to be, and when the tone is tense and poignant the writing does an above decent job reflecting that. The pacing is never dull, if deliberately less rushed(Goblet of Fire) or glacial(Deathly Hallows Part 1) as some of the other entries, and the storytelling is always interesting and compelling while never convoluted.

The acting is very good. Rupert Grint is great as he consistently is, Emma Watson while not quite as good as she was in Deathly Hallows Part 1 gives one of her better performances of the series, Maggie Smith and John Hurt are always good value and while I didn't find him easy to warm to at first until Half-Blood Prince in his brief but relevant appearance Michael Gambon is also good. Helena Bonham-Carter, David Thewlis, Gary Oldman, Robbie Coltrane and Tom Felton while neither are at their best here bring a pleasing sheen to the film. Three actors in particular I found stood out and gave their best performances of the series. One is Daniel Radcliffe, at first I found him likable yet wooden with some questionable delivery, however overtime I think he's grown with more emotional range than usual. Two is Alan Rickman, while I have considered him one of the more consistent actors of this series him and the character of Snape really shine here, Rickman is especially good in the Snape's memory sequence. Three is Ralph Fiennes, I think it helps that like Snape Voldemort is given more scope here, that said Fiennes is appropriately sinister in the role and certainly looks the part.

In conclusion, a wonderful film and for me the best of the series. And I still stand by my initial feeling that it was better filming the book as two movies, it would've have felt far too rushed as one. 9/10 Bethany Cox.

The final film in the series certainly delivers in terms of spectacle - and not a small amount of darkness despite the need to tie it up with an appropriate ending. The final revelations of Rowling's brilliantly conceived world show a view of good and evil, and the place of people in a world that is both, as more subtle and nuanced than many of the fantasy/science-fiction epics. It's all a bit too long and overblown, but the skill of the world-building is palpable - it's always a place people will want to return to, a set of characters we'll want to spend time with.

Harry Potter is a series of films about the fight against evil wizards, released since 2001 and based on the books of the English writer J. K. Rowling. The film consists of 10 parts in the fantasy genre, which received 8 nominations in the award. 
    The plot with each part is both exciting and terrifying. On his 11th birthday, Harry learns of his magical powers. He and his friends are destined to fight against evil wizards. In each part of the film, new acquaintances and adventures are added, taking place in the magical school of Hogwarts. 
    The acting is amazing, spectacular and brilliant. The film's biggest stars are Daniel Radcliffe, Rupert Grint and Emma Watson. As for the special effects, they are absolutely incredible. 
    All in all, Harry Potter is one of the best movies I've seen in a long time. It is the most outstanding film in the history of cinema. You shouldn't miss it!

The one 1/2 down-grade I gave it was actually due to the final duel scene with Harry & Voldemort, right after Neville Longbottom kills Voldemort's snake, Nagini, with the Sword of Griffindor. The simple cracking of Voldemort's face and then scattering away in the wind in tiny pieces was a complete slap in the face to audiences that deserved a MUCH more intense demise after following this movie series for 10 years. Lets face it, if we started our kids on the first movie at age six, they would have been sixteen when the last installment was released. I'm fairly confident they could have handled a more severe send-off to one of the screen's most hated characters. Did anyone in the theater you attended applaud loudly and yell vocally when Voldemort was defeated. Our's was packed and not a peep from anyone when he was killed by Harry. There you have it. It would have brought the ending to OUTSTANDING, IMHO.

Arriva finalmente lo scontro finale, la battaglia tra bene e male si svolge nel luogo in cui quasi tutti gli eventi della serie si sono svolti, riassumendo alla perfezione tutta la saga.
Purtroppo la battaglia è troppo rapida per potersela godere a pieno, incentrata totalmente sui personaggi principali, lasciando pochissimi secondi a tutti i comprimari.
Memorabili i due minuti di riassunto concessi al personaggio di Severus Piton, commoventi e potenti come pochi.
Finale all'altezza di una saga cinematografica che segnerà la storia della cinematografia per la lungimiranza ed il coraggio con cui è stata intrapresa e portata alla conclusione.
Come onnnn this has to be the worst HP movie, or one of the two worst movies of HP.

Amazing .. Goosebumps. Best of all the harry potter movies. A great Thrill ride. Every thing was all setup in all its last installments, This movie delivers a great mixture of thrill, adventure, comedy, emotions, action.. and a great faceoff between death lord and Harry potter ... It Ends and It Ends well .. WOW
spoiler: the hallows are voldemorts children

I don't have much to say here that hasn't already been said. This movie hardly competes with any other because of its circumstances where the somewhat flawed buildup was all shoved into a different movie entirely, leaving this one with the sole task of delivering a lengthy fan-service climax to the entire franchise with a practically unlimited budget and plenty of characters whose arcs were 95% finished. The plot revelations were the best part of the movie, followed by the special effects, then the acting prowess displayed by the leads (especially Fiennes and Bonham Carter in this one), then the dramatic and memorable film score. The most touching scene of the movie and perhaps the entire series for me was Hermione offering to go into the woods with Harry - it came off incredibly altruistic and human, hitting me right in the feels unexpectedly in a way that Snape's memories did not. There were some things I would've preferred to see happen with the characters than what did, though that's mainly a very minor gripe with the source material. This was extremely successful as an ending to the series and deserves its spot as the highest-rated movie in it, even if that's mostly for getting to adapt only the exciting parts of one of the novels. Kudos!
This movie ended the Harry Potter series on a terrible note. I can't believe this shameful. And after the success of the earlier films too!

Here we are at the end of arguably the best YA series of novels adapted to film of all time. If the previous three film (Order of Phoenix, Half-Blood Prince, and Deathly Hallows part 1) if these films were the resistance underground films, this one is the out and out war film with wall to wall action, separated by a few tender quieter moments in between. In the last stand battle of Hogwarts everybody showed their bravery. Dame Maggie Smith's Prof. Mcgonagall got a moment to show how badass she is taking over Hogwarts, and Neville Longbottom was one of the most courageous young wizards, standing up for the Dark Lord himself. He was so brave he earned the right to wield the Sward of Gryffindor and truly save the day. That said, the true sacrifice came from Snape, the most misunderstood hero of the story. He gave up his entire life and managed to live as an outcast for years just to protect Harry and fool the Dark Lord, he managed to have a final moment with Harry which just made me very emotional.
The final showdown between Harry and Voldemort was short and sweet. The Dark Lord's hubris lead to his downfall after our heros managed to take him down piece by piece working together, and utilizing the Deathly Hallows for good not for personal gains. The film then was bookended with a happy scene at the train to Hogwarts 16 years later, with the new generation of wizards starting their first year at the school. It is a lovely scene that mirrors the one from the first film, and I could not think of a better ending.

Amazing conclusion to the series, the film is one big emotional journey, with great action scenes and more quiet moments, one of the highlights is the score and pacing of the story. However the final showdown between Harry Potter and Voldemort, where they chase each other around Hogwarts, was weird and unnecessary, and Neville's shining moment from the book was anticlimactic in the movie. The time wasted on Potter/Voldemort chase could have been used on more important scenes such as the death of Fred Weasley or another important character. But the movie is still fantastic and manages to be a satisfying ending
The heartwarming and heartbreaking end to an amazing story is so shocking and action packed. Stakes also add to the fact that i believe it's the greatest Harry Potter movie

A fitting conclusion to a long adventure. There were many moments during the my most recent viewing of this after watching the subsequent films, where I got goosebumps and chills. One of the things that makes this finale work so well, is the way it utilizes elements from each chapter that led up to it. It's a different viewing experience when you watch this movie after all the others. You catch details and connection that add to the overall experience. In some ways it is reminiscent of Avengers: Endgame in that, everything comes together without failing to deliver. It seems like having the chance to direct multiple films allowed David Yates to accumulate a sensibility for what worked and what didn't. This is evident in an ending that brings together the most important parts of the books, and nowhere is this more evident than in Part 2.

As a big Harry Potter fan this movie is everything you could want! They tied up a lot of great storylines and gave great fan service. It was great being with the characters you've loved over 10 years for one last adventure! Big revelations to enjoy!

Along with The Dark Knight Rises, Avengers: Endgame and The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King, Deathly Hallows part 2 is a showing of a perfect finale. Every loose end, every character arc is resolved in a satisfying way, all structed around what is, in esscenece a war movie. The soundtrack is particularly striking, and the multiple long-takes and callbacks are very well-executed. The Resurrection Stone in the Forest, the Princes tale, the dragon flight, there are so many thrilling and emotional moments in this dark but wildly entertaining and rewatchable climax to a franchise I hold very close to my heart | Grade: A+

Directly following the events of "Deathly Hollows Part 1" Harry (Danielle Radcliffe), Hermione (Emma Watson), and Ron (Rupert Grint) continue their search for Voldemorts (Ralph Fiennes) horcruxs. 

This film is in my opinion the best in the franchise. This film is the shortest of the series which means it is very faced paced compared to the rest. The film gets going very quickly and never really slows down because it doesn't need to. At this point they have developed the characters and all of the plot lines which mean this film doesn't need to set up anything, it just needs to close. Everything was ended in an extremely satisfying way. Whether it be the emotional end of Snape (Alan Rickman), the long awaited relationship between Hermione and Ron, or the death of Voldemort this is an extremely satisfying film.

The scene that gives me goosebumps whenever I watch it is when McGonagall (Maggie Smith) activates the guards. The combination of music and cinematography makes for one of my favourite scenes in the entire franchise. 

The action in this film is extremely well handled and we get to see a lot of these characters get their moment to shine. In particular Neville's (Matthew Lewis) moment when he gives a heartwarming speech at then proceeds to kill Nagini is one of the greatest character moments in the series.

There are some confusing points in this film that I think definitely could've been polished up and there are a few to many things that happen off camera but it doesn't take to much away from the masterpiece that this film is.

Un altro problema di questi quattro film è che non riescano a far funzionare correttamente il titolo al loro interno. 
La battaglia di Hogwarts in questo film è senza dubbio emozionante, ma poteva anche non ricoprire un ruolo così vasto da dimenticare il resto.

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows concludes the long running franchise in epic fashion, with a finale that satisfies on an emotional and visceral level. Tying everything together from a 8 film franchise is no small task, and I think the filmmakers have truly nailed it here. There is no shortage of character moments, bringing back classic fan favorites as well as introducing some characters that are "new" to the audience but feel like they have been a part of this universe all along. The performances are wonderful across the board, practically all of the actors we have known from Sorcerer's Stone turn in their best performance in this film. Rickman, Radcliffe, Grint, Watson, and many more bring their A-game for this finale. The visuals are at their best, with some truly epic and kinetic moments of CGI-enhanced magical action. Many threads are picked up on, well connected, with a tidy bow on top and it's filled to the brim with fan-pleasing moments. Unless you genuinely don't care for the Harry Potter series, you should be truly impressed with this conclusion.

Left here is no longer just a literary legacy --- an artistic one rather.

Acting: 10

Daniel Radcliffe continues to be sensational in his role as Harry Potter as he embraces Potter's ascension into manhood. Rupert Grint (Ron) and Emma Watson (Hermione) shine yet again playing his dedicated friends and sidekicks. You can tell that the three of them have formed such a strong bond over the eight movies as their synergy is extremely on point.

Beginning: 4

Characters: 10
This final film pulls out all the stops as it's an all-out good vs. evil war. Teeming with amazing characters, I was hardpressed trying to uncover who exactly my favorite was. Potter is wonderful, yes, but so are dozens of others literally. I was really impressed with the maturation of Ron's character. It can be hard at times developing a sidekick but in some ways, Ron's journey to completion is just as satisfying as Harry's.

Cinematography/Visuals: 10

Conflict: 10
This one is for all the marbles so they hold nothing back when it comes to amazing action sequences. The battles sprawl all across Hogwarts filled with dope magic and wonder. Sparks fly in abundance of blacks, greens and reds across a dark backdrop, a spectacular display. Sometimes you have no idea who's even winning, but it looks damn cool.

Entertainment Value: 10
Potter vs. Voldemort alone is worth the price of admission. The battle definitely lives up to the hype. Even moreso to see closure happen on every level is a welcome treat. Outside of a slow(ish) start, the movie is enjoyable from beginning to end.

Memorability: 10

Pace: 10
The beauty of the final book being done in two parts for the movie is they definitely saved the best for last. All the best battles and memorable scenes are jam-packed into Part 2, causing things to fly by at a breakneck pace. Just over two hours, the final installment just flies by.

Plot: 10
JK Rowling wraps up this beautiful adventure quite nicely. The thing I keep going back to and have an immense amount of respect for: No loose ends. The stakes are higher than ever in this story that succeeds with a few cool twists along the way.

Resolution: 10

Overall: 94
The magical battles alone are enough to make Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 2 worth a watch. With the combination of rich characters who each get a proper sendoff, a speedy pace, and a chunk of memorable moments, this is a movie to remember.

Over-reliance upon book lore has been a long-term problem for this franchise, and that issue has only grown more pronounced as the film adaptations enter their final stretch. I have no idea how anyone could make sense of Deathly Hallows 2 without keeping a store of such information, fresh and reliable, somewhere in their noggin. Maybe a Cliff's Notes handbook and a hair-trigger pause button would suffice. Casually tossing about complicated concepts like wand allegiance, multiplying spells, hallows and horcruxes, the film skims along at a high speed, in breathless pursuit of flashier material. Of that, fortunately, there's plenty, and those bits are loaded with well-constructed callbacks to the previous films. The action scenes are constant highlights, excellent in concept and in execution; a fitting farewell, in their own way, for the series at large.

Quieter character moments are more of a mixed bag. Snape gets his big spotlight scene, after being completely ignored in the previous chapter, but most of the younger cast members are swept up in the desperate search for a soul mate. Everybody just wants to pair off, to hit that convenient epilogue with a litter of kids tugging at their shoestrings. Despite simmering for years and years, in many cases, such romances play more like a series of checked boxes than natural, heartfelt outpourings of emotion. Ron and Hermione are a prime example. The moment of their long-germinating embrace was evidently a difficult scene for the actors, who literally grew up together on-set, and their discomfort is clear on the screen. The kiss feels like an awkward, instantly-regretted smooch between friends, not a grand culmination, and that robs power from these beloved characters' storybook ending. They probably should've got that out of the way several movies earlier anyway. Here, in the midst of a hectic chase and a frenzied battle, even an effective payoff would've been lost in the mix.

Which is another recurring issue that this film never really settles. There's enough material for three movies in here (or a seven-hundred page book, as it were) and in trying to please everyone, to fit it all in, the whole package fades into a fleeting, dizzying wash. Nothing gets a chance to breathe, lest a different scene meet the cutting room floor. Crucial time is cut from meaningful points in the main narrative, dampening their impact, to cram in a few smaller, crowd-pleasing tidbits. But those, too, are over and done with so quickly that they hardly seem worth the effort.

In the end, we get (nearly) everything, without necessitating another weird mid-stream cutaway, but nothing is half as rewarding as I'd expected. A stumble over the finish line, in other words; a film that hits the novel's plot points but completely misses its spirit. Could've been worse, I guess, but it also could've been so much better.

Wow, that's what you will say when you watch this concluding film in the Harry Potter series, it's just amazing how consistently great this series is especially considering that it has eight movies and the last one is truly the best of them all. David Yates closed this series with a deeply moving conclusion to these film adaptations and I am amazed how well this two-part finale worked out, you can totally see how this last book warranted being split in two and it was honestly for the best. I am very pleased with how they wrapped up all of the plotlines and made them feel like a satisfying conclusion that we've been building up to for the past 10 years, the journey that these characters all went on was well worth the reward considering how many hours we put into supporting their development and it absolutely works for me, this was a great heart-wrenching finale with some really good action sprinkled throughout, it is pretty fast-paced and it never fails to entertain on every level including emotionally. The flashback with Snape and Lilly was so heartbreaking and well done, I felt for Snape so much and loved him even more as a character and Alan Rickman played him to perfection, scenes like that test how emotionally invested we got in the characters and for me, my heartstrings tugged every single time. This movie makes the weaker movies Half-Blood Prince and the Columbus films totally worth watching, not that they were bad, but they didn't stand on their own as movies nearly as well as the other ones, this pays off all of the time you invested in this series and it feels cohesive and complete. Another amazing thing in this film is that the stakes have never been higher and they feel so real, it feels like there will be consequences and it makes this even more intense, with the deaths of Lupin, Tonks, and Fred, it made everyone feel vulnerable and human in a world filled with magic, it got us to worry about everyone we know and made us feel justice when Harry achieves victory. I greatly appreciated that David Yates didn't milk this last movie by making it long and drawn out for no reason, it does its job quickly, it takes more time with the character development when it needs to, it isn't boring and it feels complete and satisfying, I only wish that there was more time given to Malfoy and actually having him going through with siding with Harry, his character arc feels incomplete and just hanging there with no resolution. This is the shortest film in the series and it works very well as a conclusion, it feels earned, the stakes are real, it consistently entertains and I get emotional every time. This is my favorite film in the series and it caps off this franchise very nicely.

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 is absolutely breathtaking! David Yates has been a favorable director for these films, and he really showcased his talents here. He crafted so many gorgeous shots, with a couple new creative tricks, while Mark Day's editing was absolutely seamless, really knitting the scenes together beautifully.

David Yates let Part 1 take all the set up hits, and completely focused on making this a high octane, blast of fun! Yates does an amazing job of bringing all of the former events and foreshadowing together, to create countless amazing moments! There were so many twists and turns, keeping the narrative fresh, while moving at such a brisk pace with great momentum. Yates does a fantastic job of setting up this really dark and dreary tone, backed up by the amazing cinematography, and a great score, while really balancing the emotional keys well with the dark tone.

It has been a great honor and pleasure to have seen all of these characters grow and mature, over the seventeen years of the saga - it's truly sad to say that it's over. Yates does an amazing job of bringing in all of the characters from the past films, and balancing them super well within the narrative. There were just countless great character moments, displaying their true talents in their own way. After all this time, you can really feel and understand the characters motives and feelings, because everyone is fleshed out so nicely, having great chemisty across the board.

As a finale should be, the magic and action sequences were off the charts! It was by far the best showing of their magical abilities, having so many intriguing sequences! The amount of stakes that were set was amazing, having constant tention throughout the entire narrative.

Overall, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2, is phenomenal! It is by far the most entertaining film of the saga, and arguably the best; I just can't put it over The Prisoner of Azkaban!
A worthy final that does right what part one did wrong. The action is fantastic and the story emotional. Sure to please fans of all ages.

Non esattamente il gran finale che mi sarei aspettato dopo la qualità di tutto il franchise in generale. La conclusione di questa colossale saga cinematografica è assolutamente positiva per ogni tipologia di pubblico, ma cade in errori estremamente banali che dovevano essere obbligatoriamente evitati. In primis, non c'è sufficiente spazio narrativo per le morti dei vari personaggi, che cadono senza motivazione senza che gli venga data meritata giustizia. Inoltre, nella seconda parte della pellicola lo scontro finale risulta parzialmente frettoloso e non convincente al cento per cento. Stupende invece alcune piccole scelte registiche e narrative che inglobano tutto il percorso dei personaggi iniziato con il primissimo film. Nel complesso si tratta di un finale leggermente sottotono rispetto alle previsioni, ma che riesce comunque ad offrire emozioni forti e sincere a tutti i numerosi appassionati.

When I think of a stellar movie, I immediately think of this box office smash hit. 

The story is a continuation of the story of the famous Harry Potter. It starts with the bubbling wizarding war that is about to topple over in instant destruction. You can feel the tension in the air with the character's breathing and body language. The way that the story unfolds is like nothing ever seen. In my mind, it doesn't follow the status quo of Disney or Paramount (love stories, buddy stories, road trips and such).

The characters are stellar. They play their parts phenomenally. The casting of Ian Hart, Helena Bonham Carter, and of course, Daniel Radcliffe was an amazing choice. The performances really dazzle audiences to this day. You can feel the warmth of the greeting when Harry comes to Hogwarts for the final battle. It gives off the impression that there really is such a thing as Hogwarts.

The setting feels so real and authentic that you sometimes wonder if it all was CGI and a blue screen. They characters interact in such a way that it makes you feel that they're all really best friends and not people from random parts of Europe. The chemistry between the characters is sensational.

Overall an amazing movie and I wouldn't miss it for the world!!!!!!!!

David Yates directed a wonderful finale for his adaptation of J. K. Rowling's iconic children's series: Harry Potter. Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part II (2011) is not only far superior to the dull Part I, but a tight picture that ties up all the loose ends, answering questions audiences have held onto for a decade, giving satisfying conclusions for all its characters. Yates directs The Deathly Hallows Part II with a focused perspective, swift pace, and attention to detail for explaining various mysteries left unanswered by previous films in the series. 

J. K. Rowling's writing is precise and interesting as she connects the dots between Snape's deeds by shifting his crimes into sacrifices in a devastating final performance from Alan Rickman. Yates' direction makes Snape's backstory appear ambiguous like Snape could have even been Harry's father despite book implications. Rowling revealing that Snape had been protecting Harry due to his love of Harry's mother Lily Potter is endearing, devastating, and shocking all at once. Finding out Harry was a horcrux too, who needs to die is sad, but gets resolved in a neat way. I don't particularly care for the train station waypoint to Heaven as it's a very on the nose metaphor beneath the series, but it gets the point across I suppose.

Alexandre Desplat's score is epic and sweeping with grandeur worthy of Harry Potter's finale. It's too bad it's not as magical and memorable as John Williams' original score, but Desplat brings fiery composition to his music. I'm quite happy Harry and Ginny end up together, while I guess it was fate for Hermione and Ron as their relationship was developed from the beginning. Daniel Radcliffe, Bonnie Wright, Emma Watson, and Rupert Grint all bring their best for this emotional final film in the Harry Potter series.

Ralph Fiennes is fearsome and scary with his Shakespearean take on Lord Voldemort. Jason Isaac is great as the cowardly Lucius Malfoy, meanwhile Helen McCrory and Tom Felton are excellent as the redeemed villains Narcissa and Draco Malfoy. Helena Bonham Carter is excellent fun in a more playful role for Bellatrix in all her insane antics.

Overall, it's a fun last movie that is emotionally poignant and enthralling narratively.
It's so good. It is so good. The way it ties back to the other films, the emotion it has, and the epic ending to it all... I love this movie. I love this series. I think everyone should too.

While the expectations were certainly sky-high for the final entry to a film series that defined a generation, Deathly Hallows Part 2 serves as a satisfactory, if not particularly radical, conclusion. Seeing actors mature and adapt to their roles over more than a decade ultimately imparts more of an impact than the narrative itself, though new viewers may be forced to assess the merits of the series more objectively. This is my favorite Harry Potter movie and one of my top 10 favorite movies of all time. The acting performances in this movie was stupendous especially from Daniel Radcliffe, Emma Watson, Rupert Grint, Ralph Fiennes, Michael Gambon, Maggie Smith, Warwick Davis, Julie Walters, Ciarán Hinds, Matthew Lewis, Alan Rickman, Helena Bonham Carter, John Hurt, Evanna Lynch, Tom Felton, Kelly Macdonald, Bonnie Wright, and Helen McCrory. The writing, story, plot, and screenplay were excellent. The maturity the characters had in this movie and how well-developed they have become was fantastic. The visual effects were spectacular especially the Gringott's dragon, when Voldemort blasted the barrier on Hogwarts, the Fire animals, Nagini the snake, and when Harry and Voldemort have their final battle. The direction that David Yates took this film was terrific. The makeup and hair was outstanding especially Griphook, Voldemort, Bogrod, and all of the Goblins at Gringotts. The costumes that ever actor wore were amazing. The filming was gorgeously done. The scenery and sets were awesome and beautiful at the same time. Also the films score was wonderful. This was a A+ film.
this movie has it all!

Characters and subplots come out of nowhere in the last Harry Potter film, though they rush it along to its explosive conclusion. The digital effects and music are often quite beautiful, and even if the final battle fails to reach Lord of the Rings levels of epic, Harry's story reaches an emotive end, as long hidden revelations finally come to light.
